title: Maryann McConnell
text:
Maryann McConnell is a <a href="Canadian%20people">Canadian</a> <a href="snooker">snooker</a> and <a href="Pool%20%28cue%20sports%29">pool</a> player. She was runner-up in the 1984 Professional <a href="World%20Women%27s%20Snooker%20Championship">World Women's Snooker Championship</a>, and has won numerous <a href="Pool%20%28cue%20sports%29">pool</a> tournaments in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>.
Biography.
McConnell started playing at the age of 24, at the <a href="University%20of%20Guelph">University of Guelph</a> in <a href="Ontario">Ontario</a> where she studied from 1974 to 1980. She later drove daily to a pool hall in nearby <a href="Kitchener%2C%20Ontario">Kitchener</a>, where she played snooker, practicing for as much as eight hours a day.
In 1980, 1981 and 1983, she was a quarter-finalist in the <a href="World%20Women%27s%20Snooker%20Championship">World Women's Snooker Championship</a>. For 1984, separate amateur and professional events were staged. McConnell entered the professional event, and reached the final, losing 2–4 to <a href="Mandy%20Fisher">Mandy Fisher</a>. At one time, McConnell was the second-ranked woman player.
She was the runner-up in the 1984 National Express Grand Prix ladies snooker series, and spent the summer of 1985 living in Saudi Arabia.
In 1991 she took part in the <a href="1991%20World%20Masters">1991 World Masters</a>, losing in her first matches in both the women's singles, and the women's doubles (with J. Page). In the mixed doubles she fared slightly better, partnering <a href="Alain%20Robidoux">Alain Robidoux</a> to wins over <a href="Neal%20Foulds">Neal Foulds</a> and J. Page, and over <a href="seed%20%28sports%29">seeded</a> <a href="Terry%20Griffiths">Terry Griffiths</a> and <a href="Mandy%20Fisher">Mandy Fisher</a>, before losing to <a href="James%20Wattana">James Wattana</a> and S. Smith.
In 1992 she beat Sherri Richardson 4–2 in the semi-final, and Rhondda Jackman in the final to win the Canadian Women's Championship, retaining the title that she had won at the previous staging in 1983.
McConnell has a degree in fine art, and runs a pool hall, Alberni Valley Billiards. She has four children. Her late husband Robin Woodward died in 2013, and had worked with McConnell managing the business.
Titles and achievements.
Snooker
Nine-ball Pool
Eight-Ball Pool
Scotch Doubles (Pool)
